awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Clean, Inexpensive, and Carbon-free Energy from a Toxic Waste
awd_abstract_narration:
This SBIR Phase I project will develop a unique packed bed (no catalyst) reactor that can internally maintain temperatures for converting H2S to hydrogen and sulfur.  This reactor helps to defeat the equilibrium limitation of the standard Claus Reaction and in addition allows one to capture hydrogen which is otherwise expended as a waste.

The broader/commercial impact of the project will be to focus attention on the production of sulfur from petroleum refinery waste streams of H2S instead of treating the  hydrogen as a waste exhaust gas (as the Claus process does). This process allows for the use of hydrogen both as a fuel and also to drive turbines and thereby save energy.  Furthermore, hydrogen is a carbonless fuel.

por.por_cntn:
Under this Phase I Small Business Innovative Research
project, Innovative Energy Solution modified its superadiabatic autothermal
reforming process, a partial oxidation process marketed as the SuperATR, to
increase the hydrogen yield from hydrogen sulfide cracking.  In reforming hydrogen sulfide to hydrogen and
sulfur, the process achieved a 38% hydrogen yield thus surpassing its main
objective by one point.  In effect,
Innovative Energy Solution achieved another milestone with the 38% hydrogen
yield from hydrogen sulfide.  During the
development of the original SuperATR process a couple of years back, the 31%
yield represented a milestone then as it as the highest yield in a thermal
process.  Until to that time; the highest
yield (22%) was obtained by a competing process under development by Alberta
Sulfur Research Limited, Canada.  The
yield could have reached above 40%, with higher firing rates for higher
temperatures.  But the simple bench-scale
SuperATR reactor, constructed with quartz, did not permit higher firing rates
due to safety limits.  With natural gas
reforming, a 65% hydrogen yield was obtained with the bench-scale reactor and
64% in the pilot unit. 



 



The new and improved reformer will be marketed in the SuperATR-max
brand.  Those improvements were achieved
by significant modifications made to the existing bench and pilot-plant scale
reactors to include: a) addition of a new reaction zone
at the reactor’s mid-axial center and b) improved heat exchangers.  The additional reaction zone, resulting in a
total of three reactions zones in a single chamber, effectively turn the whole
reactor into a high temperature volume. 
The improved heat exchangers operate with a high circulation rate of
water, as the coolant, to quickly quench the product stream for preventing
recombination reactions.  The company
conducted a wide array of experiments reforming both hydrogen sulfide and
natural gas in two types of SuperATR reactors: 1) a bench scale for hydrogen
sulfide along with natural gas and 2) a pilot plant scale reactor for natural
gas.  It was concluded that four factors
produce the highest hydrogen yield:



i)    
High Temperature: This requirement
is key to overcoming the equilibrium limitation of hydrogen sulfide reforming. 



ii)   
Residence time: A critical parameter
that must be coupled with temperature.



iii)  
Fast quenching: This is needed to
prevent recombination reactions between hydrogen and sulfur to revert back to
hydrogen sulfide since the reverse reaction is also fast.   



iv)  
Ultra-substoichiometric operation: Operation
in the ultra-substoichiometric, where much less oxygen is consumed, prevents
formation of sulfur dioxide, a pollutant.
